entry.title: Still problems with bindung in SAP Document Reporting Complance after SAP solved the main problem.
entry.content:
Hi, 

it seems SAP experienced issues with changing certificates in the central truststore within their own infrastructure around December 3rd and 4th, 2025. We also had to change one of our certificates but encountered significant problems with the new certificate from our hosting provider for our on-premise systems. and Cloud Connection The SAP DRC connection on the production instance and PRD ECC are working again after I rebound them with the same certificate as before. However, the test system uses a different certificate, and I couldn't get it working with the new one. Changing the certificate again didn't help either. A login dialog for the Integration Suite always appears via EDOC_COCKPIT, but there's no connection to the Integration Suite. Do you have any suggestions for a solution in this case?

Thx, Uwe

entry.title: [Q] Hana Datanase not starting after providing double CPUs and double RAM memory ?
entry.content:
OK, thanks that all my writings got lost before I could publish them, so I have the pleasure to type it all again !!

We have a Hana Database, replicating to two other servers via HSR. Due to severe performance problems we have decided to
double the number of CPUs and provide the double amount of RAM memory to ONLY ONE of the servers, because we do not have
that much available resources to do this everywhere.

After the uplift, we were unable to start Hana on that Server. There was absolutely no significant error message in the log files !!!
Then we have tried to set the global_allocation_limit in global.ini to the amount of memory the Server had previously. ONLY after that we could see only this significant error message:

Uncaught remote exception left during request destruction: can't handle 'lic/license_measurement' while not assigned to volume on active channel (since 3489mues)

I suppose that the hardware key got changed and now the database ended up with an invalid license and this prevents it from starting.
I would gladly generate a new license, however how can I apply it when even SYSTEMDB is not coming up ?? I did not find any way
to manage licenses directly on OS level. The saplikey command doesn't exist on Hana systems...

Did anyone else has ever had the same problem ? Is there anything we could have done to prevent this from happening ? I think Hana should come up at least for 30 minutes to allow us to install a correct license.... This is really incredible. Now we will probably need to
reinstall the database !!! Thanks for letting me know!

entry.title: Re: Calculate price with null values
entry.content:
@Dustin 

I think it should be possible using a model level calculation. Define a calculation something like below. [PL120] is the measure in my case.

ITERATE(IF(NOT(ISNULL([PL120] ) ) ,[PL120] ,PRIOR() ) ,[PL120] , [d/Date])

Output:

LC_Prev is the calculated account. [PL120] is the original account.

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: Calculate price with null values
entry.content: @nikhil, that's exactly what I was looking for. Thank you very much!

entry.title: Re: Still problems with bindung in SAP Document Reporting Complance after SAP solved the main proble
entry.content: Hi Uwe, if PROD is working with the previous certificate but the TEST system isn’t binding with the new one, it sounds like the issue is specific to the trust configuration rather than the certificate itself. I’d suggest double-checking whether the new certificate is correctly installed in the trust store used by the test environment and that the full certificate chain is included. Also make sure the Integration Suite destination in the test system is pointing to the correct alias. Sometimes just re-importing the full chain and restarting the connection can fix this behavior, especially if EDOC_COCKPIT is prompting for login instead of making a direct handshake.

entry.title: 「クリーン コア」は本当に新しい概念なのか？（Is "Clean Core" Really a New Concept?）
entry.content:
「クリーン コア」は本当に新しい概念なのか？ —— 温故知新で紐解く

(※English translation is available in the latter half of this article.)
(※本稿はJSUGテクニカル部会オピニオンリーダーとしての経験に基づく個人の見解であり、個人の所属企業およびJSUG等の組織の公式な見解を代表するものではありません。また文書の一部は生成AIにより作成しています。内容の正確性などを保証するものではありませんので、情報の活用はご自身の判断で行ってください。)

「それ、昔から言っていませんでしたか？」

JSUGテクニカル部会の活動を通じ、ユーザー企業の皆様や、SAP社のエキスパートたちと会話することが多い日々です。最近のコンファレンス等でも、「クリーン コア（Clean Core）」という言葉を聞かない日はありません。皆さんもそうではないでしょうか。

しかし、長年SAPの世界に身を置く皆様の中には、ある種の「既視感」を覚える方も多いはずです。

  • 「競争力の源泉とならない業務は標準機能を使おう（Fit to Standard）」 ・・・今

  • 「アドオンを作るなら、BAPIのような標準インターフェースを使おう」 ・・・少し前

  • 「アップグレード障害になるから、標準コードの直接修正（モディフィケーション）はやめよう」 ・・・20年ぐらい前

これらは、10年、いや20年前から私たちが議論し、目指してきた「あるべき姿」です。言葉こそ違えど、その大きな方向性に違いはないと感じています。

先日、部会に参加いただいた方から**「SAPさんはよく『クリーン コア』と言いますが、どうなれば『クリーンになった』と言えるのでしょうか？ 納得できる評価指標が欲しいのです」**という「問い」を投げかけられました。

その時、私は即答できませんでした。なぜなら、単に「アドオンを外に出しました（Side-by-Side）、公開APIだけを使っています」というだけでは、かつての「ABAPアドオンや、VB/Javaで作った外部アプリがBAPIを叩く構成」と本質的に何が違うのか、その差分を明確に説明できないもどかしさを感じたからです。

本稿では、この「変わらない本質」と、最新の拡張モデル（A-Dレベル）への進化、そしてAI時代における新たな意味を整理し、私たちが目指すべき方向性を再考したいと思います。

(この記事は SAPアドベントカレンダー 2025 の 12月8日分の記事として執筆しています。)

 

 

「場所」が変わっただけのスパゲッティ

まず、私たちが直視すべきは、「クリーン コア」という言葉が独り歩きし、「ERPの中にコードがなければ良い」という形式的なゴールに向かってしまっている懸念です。

海外のSAPコミュニティ（SAP Mentorsなど）では、既存の低品質なカスタムコードを、リファクタリング（設計の見直し）もせずにそのままクラウド基盤（SAP BTP）へ移行する手法に対し、**「分散モノリス（Distributed Monolith）」**という厳しい言葉で警鐘が鳴らされています。

「ゴミを部屋（ERP）からガレージ（BTP）に移しても、家全体が綺麗になったとは言えない」――ある海外アーキテクトの言葉は、痛烈に核心を突いています。

複雑怪奇なロジックをそのままクラウド上に持ち出し、大量のAPI通信を行えば、パフォーマンスは劣化し、障害時の原因究明は困難になります。これは私たちが過去、外部連携システムで苦労した歴史の繰り返しになりかねません。

「作る場所」を変えること自体は目的ではありません。「ビジネスの変化にどう対応するか」という目的を見失ってはいけないのです。

 

ストイックな理想から現実解へ：3-TierモデルからA-Dレベルへの進化

ここで、最近のSAPの戦略転換についても触れておく必要があります。当初、Clean Core戦略の実装ガイドラインとして「3-Tier（3階層）モデル」が提示されていました。

  • Tier 1: クラウドネイティブな公開APIのみを使用（Clean）

  • Tier 2: 公開APIがない場合のラッパー（Conditionally Clean）

  • Tier 3: 従来のABAP記述（Not Clean）

 

このモデルは非常にストイックで、「最新のクラウド作法（Tier 1）以外は認めない」という圧力が強いものでした。しかし、私たちJSUGテクニカル部会の議論においても、この点についてはSAP社の担当者に対して繰り返し疑問を呈してきました。

「BAPI（Business Application Programming Interface）は、そもそもSAP標準機能を安全に拡張するために、SAP自身が提供・保証してきた標準インターフェースではないか？ それを使っているのに『Not Clean』とされるのは矛盾している」

現場の実情としても、20年以上安定稼働しているBAPIを、単に「Tier 1の作法ではない」という理由だけで作り直すことは、コスト対効果の面で正当化できません。

実は、こうした声を上げていたのは日本のユーザーだけではなかったようです。ドイツのDSAGやアメリカのASUGといった世界中の主要なユーザーグループからも、「既存の安定したBAPI資産まで否定するのは現実的ではない」「Tier 2のラッパー作成は無駄な工数だ」といった同様のフィードバックが寄せられていました。

こうした世界中のユーザーコミュニティの「現場の声」を受け、SAPは2024年から2025年にかけて方針を軌道修正し、より現実的で洗練された**「Clean Core Extensibility Levels（A-Dレベル）」**という新モデルを導入しました。

(※各レベルの詳細な定義と3-Tierモデルとの比較については、本稿末尾のAppendixを参照ください)


新しい評価軸：A-Dレベルの衝撃

レベル判定定義と現場視点での解釈
Level AClean未来への投資。最新のABAP CloudとReleased APIを使用する理想形。新規開発はここを目指すべき。
Level BCleanBAPIの復権。ここが重要です。従来の**BAPIやIDoc（Classic API）**の使用が、正式に「Clean Core」の一部として認められました。これらは「クラウドネイティブ」ではないかもしれませんが、「アップグレードに対して安全（Upgrade Safe）」であるという実績が評価されたのです。
Level CConditional要監視。非公開の内部オブジェクトを使用しているが、変更ログ（Changelog）等でリスク管理ができる領域。
Level DNot Cleanレッドゾーン。モディフィケーション（標準コードの直接修正）やテーブル直接更新。これこそが排除すべき「真の技術的負債」です。

この進化は、SAPが「形式的な新しさ」よりも「実質的なシステムの安定性」を優先するという、エンジニアリングとしての誠実さ（Integrity）を取り戻した結果だと、評価しています。BAPIが一定レベルであれ「Clean」と認められたことは、過去からの一貫性という観点でも整合性が取れており、我々にとっては、既存資産（Brownfield）の移行における大きな現実解となります。

 

なぜ今、再び「標準化」なのか？ —— AIという「新たな評価者」

BAPIの利用が認められた（Level B）からといって、昔ながらのアドオン開発を続けて良いわけではありません。なぜなら、当時とは決定的に異なる**「AIの台頭」**という要素があるからです。

かつて、私たちが作った独自のアドオン機能から生成されたデータを解釈するのは、トレーニングを受けた「人間」でした。人間は、多少データ構造がいびつでも、文脈（コンテキスト）で補完して業務を回すことができました。

しかし、生成AI（SAP Jouleなど）は違います。

AIが正しくデータを読み解き、気の利いた回答をするためには、データモデルが標準的であり、意味（セマンティクス）が定義されている必要があります。ここで重要になるのが、例えば「Zテーブル（アドオンテーブル）」と「CDS View」の関係です。

技術解説：なぜ AI は「Zテーブル」が嫌いなのか？

  • Zテーブルの限界（コンテキストの欠如）

    私たちが長年作り続けてきたアドオンテーブル（Zテーブル）は、システム的（あるいはAIの視点）には単なる「データの箱」です。例えば、Z_SALES_TBL というテーブルに VAL1 という項目があったとします。ABAPプログラムの中では「これは受注金額だ」というロジックが書かれていますが、データベース自体はその意味を知りません。

    AIがこのテーブルを見ても、「VAL1 が何なのか」を理解できず、誤った回答（ハルシネーション）をするか、「回答不能」となります。AIにとって、Zテーブルは**「意味不明なブラックボックス」**なのです。（※アドオンABAPプログラムの隅々までAIが解析してくれれば、また話は違うかもしれませんが）

  • CDS View の役割（意味の付与）

これに対し、S/4HANAで推奨される CDS (Core Data Services) View は、データに「意味ラベル」を貼る技術です。

「この項目は『顧客ID』である」「この項目は『通貨コード』である」といった意味論（セマンティクス）を、コード（アノテーション）として定義します。これにより、AIや外部システムは、プログラムの中身を見なくてもデータの意味を理解できるようになります。

つまり、現代における「クリーン」の定義とは、単にアドオンコードの有無ではなく、**「自社のデータが、CDS View 等を通じて、AIや外部から『解釈可能』な状態（Semantic Rich）になっているか」**という点にシフトしているのです。

 

自社のシステムを評価する「3つの新しいものさし」

部会に参加いただいた方からの「どう評価すればいいか」という問いに対しては、従来の技術的な分類（TierモデルやABCDレベル）を超えた、ビジネス視点での以下の評価軸案を共有したいと思います。


1. ビジネス適合性と代謝（Fit & Metabolism）

「標準機能を使っているか」だけでなく、「競争力を生まない機能を捨てる決断ができているか」。

A-Dモデルで言えば、Level D（モディフィケーション）を徹底的に排除し、Level B（BAPI）であってもビジネス価値の低いものは廃棄（Retire）する。この「代謝」こそが重要です。

もう少し詳しく：「6R」による断捨離 —— 捨てることは、作ることより尊い

クラウド移行には「6R」というフレームワークがありますが、アドオン整理に当てはめると、優先順位はこうなります。

  • Retire（廃止・捨てる）: これが最重要です。ある調査では、カスタムコードの最大60%は実際には使われていないか、価値を失っていると言われているとのことです。

  • Repurchase（買い換え・代替）: 「この機能、SaaSや標準機能で代替できませんか？」。作るのではなく、標準に乗り換える勇気です。

  • Refactor（作り直し）: 差別化につながる重要な機能だけを選び、Level A (ABAP Cloud/BTP) で再構築します。

  • Re-platform（そのまま移行）: Level B (Classic API) として現状維持を認める。ただし、これには「いつか捨てる」という返済計画が必要です。

 

 

2. デリバリーのアジリティ（Speed & Safety）

「BTPを使っているか」ではなく、「機能リリースの頻度が向上したか」。

もし、クラウド上で開発しているのに、リリースのリードタイムが数ヶ月かかるなら、それはアーキテクチャかプロセスが間違っています。GoogleのDevOps研究（DORAメトリクス）のように、変更のリードタイムやデプロイ頻度を指標とし、「変更に強いシステム」になっているかを問うてください。

もう少し詳しく：「開発者の勘」から「判断の地図（フレームワーク）」を持つ

アジリティを検討する上では、アーキテクチャや採用する技術の検討も必要です。「この機能はS/4HANAの中に作るべきか（On-Stack）、BTPに出すべきか（Side-by-Side）？」という問いに対し、SAPは**「SAP Application Extension Methodology (AEM)」という標準的な意思決定ガイドを提供しています。

  • フェーズ1: そもそも拡張が必要か？（ビジネス要件の分解）

  • フェーズ2: 必要なのはUIか、ロジックか、データか？（技術特性の評価）

  • フェーズ3: どの技術を使うのが最適解か？（デシジョンツリーによる決定）

これらも、組織として一貫性のあるアーキテクチャを維持する一助になるかもしれません。

また、BTP上での開発が無法地帯にならないよう、「ゴールデン・パス（Golden Paths）」**、少し説明的にわかりやすく言えば「「開発標準」や「開発ガイドライン」（これらは主に文書やルール）に加えて、実際に作業を効率化・自動化するための**具体的な「仕組み」**がセットになったものといったところでしょうか。その際には、以下のような新しい（モダンな）技術の利用も積極的に検討すべきかと思います。

  • 宣言的に書く (CAP/RAP): 従来のように処理手順をゴリゴリ書くのではなく、CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model) や RAP(ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model) を使い、「データモデルと意図」を定義するスタイルへ移行しましょう。これにより、コード量が減り、AIとの親和性も高まります。

  • 疎結合にする (Event Mesh): APIでガチガチにつなぐのではなく、イベント駆動アーキテクチャを採用し、システム間の依存を減らす。

 

 

3. データとAIの受容力（Readiness）

「自社のデータは、AIが理解できる状態で管理されているか」。

主要なデータが標準テーブルまたはCDS View（意味論的ビュー）経由でアクセス可能か。Level A/Bどちらの実装であっても、データモデルの意味定義がなされているかどうかが、将来のAI活用を左右する分水嶺となります。

 

おわりに：本質は「ビジネス目標に基づく整理」

「クリーン コア」という言葉の表面的な意味だけに目を向けることは危険です。 本当に必要なのは、**「使うもの（標準）と作るもの（差別化）を、ビジネス目標を踏まえて整理する」**という、極めて当たり前の、しかし実行困難な原則です。

今回、SAPが3-TierモデルからA-Dモデルへ方針転換し、BAPIを復権させたことは、私たちユーザーコミュニティが声を上げ、ベンダーと対話を重ねた成果でもあります。コミュニティでの議論がなければ、現実と乖離した理想論がそのままルール化されていたかもしれません。

「クリーン コア」の取り組みは、ECC上のコードだけが対象ではなく、企業システム全体の問題です。また、ECCからのアップグレード時期だけの一過性の取り組みでもありません。

A-Dモデルの導入により、BAPIを含む既存資産の活用（Level B）が認められたことは、私たちにとって「移行評価のハードルが下がった」という朗報です。しかし、それに甘んじて「塩漬け」を続けてはなりません。AIという新しい「評価者」が、システムデータの品質を問い続けているからです。

過去のBAPI連携の時代から脈々と続くこの原則を、AIという新しい武器を手に入れた今だからこそ、技術論ではなく本質論・経営論として完遂する。それこそが、我々が目指すべき「真のクリーン コア」への道ではないでしょうか。

この場（SAP Community）や、JSUG等のユーザーコミュニティが、理想論やバズワードをただ受け入れる場ではなく、こうした現場のリアリティを持ち寄り、本質的な議論を戦わせ知見を深める場であり続けることを願っています。

本件についても、ぜひ、皆さんからのご意見などをいただければ幸いです。

最後になりますが、本稿作成にあたって、いつも議論を戦わせ議論を深めてくださるオピニオンリーダーの皆さん、サポートしてくださっているSAPの方々、新たな気付きを与えてくださるSAP Communityの皆さん、そして「問い」を投げかけてくださったK.Uさんに、この場を借りて感謝の言葉を述べさせていただきます。（それと、いろいろ情報の収集や疑問への回答に奔走してくれたAIくんにも。）

 

Appendix：3-TierモデルからA-Dレベルへの進化サマリ

SAP S/4HANA Clean Core 戦略における拡張性モデルのパラダイムシフト

本記事のベースとなった調査レポートの要点は以下の通りです。

1. 背景と課題

従来の「3階層（3-Tier）モデル」は、クラウドネイティブ（Tier 1）以外を「Not Clean」とする傾向が強く、既存の安定したABAP資産を多く抱える日本企業にとって実現困難でした。JSUG等のユーザーコミュニティからは、「SAP標準機能であるBAPIを使った拡張まで否定されるのは矛盾している」との指摘がなされていました。

2. 新モデル（A-Dレベル）の詳細定義

SAPは拡張性を4つの成熟度レベルで再定義し、実用的な運用指針を示しました。

  • Level A (Clean Core / Future Safe):

    • 定義: 公開済みAPI (Released API) のみを使用。ABAP CloudまたはBTPでの実装。

    • 推奨: 新規開発の第一選択肢。AI活用に最適。

  • Level B (Clean Core / Upgrade Safe):

    • 定義: クラシックAPI（BAPI, IDoc, RFC等）およびクラシックフレームワーク（ALV, Dynpro等）を使用する拡張。

    • 3-Tierとの違い: ここが最大のパラダイムシフトです。3-Tierモデルでは、これらは「Tier 3（Not Clean）」とみなされるか、または「Tier 2（ラッパー作成）」として隠蔽することが求められていました。

    • 革新点: 新モデルでは、ラッパーを作成せずとも、BAPIを直接呼び出すことが「Clean Core」として公式に認定されました。これにより、「安定しているが古いためクラウド非対応」とされていた大量の既存コードが、改修不要で合格ラインに達することになります。

  • Level C (Conditional / Monitor):

    • 定義: 非公開の内部オブジェクトを使用しているが、変更ログ (Changelog / SYCM) でリスクを監視・管理することを条件に許容される拡張。

    • 3-Tierとの違い: 従来は一律に「Tier 3（禁止）」とされていたグレーゾーンに対し、「管理されたリスク（Managed Risk）」としての生存権が与えられました。代替APIが存在しない場合の現実的な回避策として機能します。

  • Level D (Not Clean / High Risk):

    • 定義: モディフィケーション、直接テーブル更新。即時の排除・改修が求められます。

3. 戦略的示唆

Level Bの認定により、Brownfield移行におけるコスト圧力を軽減しつつ、Level D（真の負債）の排除にリソースを集中させることが可能となります。これは「理想」から「現実解」への転換であり、Clean Core戦略の実効性を高めるものです。

 

 

参考情報・関連リンク

本記事の執筆にあたり、以下の議論や資料を参考にしています。深掘り学習にお役立てください。

  • クリーンコアに対する批判的考察

    • “Keep the core clean” statement considered harmful (Wout de Waal 氏のブログ): 「コアをクリーンに」という言葉が招く誤解と、分散システムの複雑性（分散モノリス）について警鐘を鳴らした必読の記事。

    • (https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/quot-keep-the-core-clean-quot-statement-considered-harmful/ba-p/13568928)

  • SAP公式のクリーンコア・拡張戦略

    • Clean Core Extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud (SAP Whitepaper): SAPが定義する最新の拡張モデル（Clean Core Levels A-D）やガバナンスに関する公式ホワイトペーパー。

    • (https://www.sap.com/documents/2024/09/20aece06-d87e-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html)

  • システム拡張の判断基準

    • SAP Application Extension Methodology: 「On-Stackで作るべきか、Side-by-Sideで作るべきか」を決定するための公式メソドロジーとデシジョンツリー。

    • (https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-btp-guidance-framework/sap-application-extension-methodology/sap-application-extension-methodology-overview)

  • アジリティの評価指標 (DORAメトリクス)

    • Understanding DORA: A DevOps Guide for Side-by-Side Extension Developers: GoogleのDevOps研究（DORA）をSAP BTP開発に適用し、デリバリーパフォーマンスを測定する方法についての解説。

    • (https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/understanding-dora-a-devops-guide-for-side-by-side-extension-developers/ba-p/14226907)

 

** Is "Clean Core" Really a New Concept? — Unraveling it by Revisiting the Past**

(※This article is a personal opinion based on my experience as an opinion leader of the JSUG Technical SIG, and does not represent the official views of the individual's company or organizations such as JSUG. Also, parts of the document were created using generative AI. We cannot guarantee the accuracy of the content, so please use the information at your own discretion.)

"Haven't We Said This Before?"

Through my activities with the JSUG (Japan SAP User Group) Technical Committee, I spend my days talking with fellow user companies and SAP experts. Recently, not a day goes by without hearing the words "Clean Core" at conferences. I’m sure many of you feel the same.

However, for those of us who have been in the SAP world for a long time, doesn't this bring about a certain sense of déjà vu?

  • "Use standard functions for non-differentiating processes (Fit to Standard)"... Current

  • "If you build add-ons, use standard interfaces like BAPI"... A little while ago

  • "Stop directly modifying standard code (Modifications) because it hinders upgrades"... About 20 years ago

These are the "ideal states" we have been discussing and aiming for over the last 10, or even 20 years. While the terminology has changed, I feel the broad direction hasn't fundamentally shifted.

Recently, a participant in our committee asked me a probing question:

"SAP often talks about 'Clean Core,' but when can we actually say a system is 'Clean'? I want a convincing evaluation metric."

At that moment, I couldn't give an immediate answer. Simply saying, "We moved add-ons outside (Side-by-Side) and are only using public APIs," didn't feel satisfying. How is that fundamentally different from the architectures of the past where external VB or Java apps called BAPIs? I felt a frustration in being unable to clearly articulate the difference.

In this post, I want to organize this "unchanging essence," the evolution to the latest extensibility model (A-D Levels), and the new meaning in the AI era to rethink the direction we should be heading.

(This article is written for the SAP Advent Calendar 2025, December 8th entry.)

 

 

Spaghetti That Just Changed Its Location

First, we must face the concern that "Clean Core" is walking on its own as a formal goal of simply "having no code inside the ERP."

In the global SAP community (including SAP Mentors), there are strict warnings against the practice of "Lift & Shift"—taking existing low-quality custom code and moving it to a cloud platform (SAP BTP) without refactoring (redesigning). This creates what is known as a "Distributed Monolith."

"Moving rubbish from your room to the garage doesn't mean the house is clean." — This quote from an overseas architect cuts to the core of the issue.

If you take complex logic and move it to the cloud as-is, executing massive amounts of API calls, performance will degrade, and troubleshooting during failures will become a nightmare. This could become a repeat of the history where we struggled with external system integrations in the past.

"Changing the location" where we build is not the goal. We must not lose sight of the true purpose: "How do we respond to business changes?"

 

 

From Stoic Ideal to Reality: Evolution from the 3-Tier Model to A-D Levels

Here, we must also touch upon SAP's recent strategic shift. Initially, the "3-Tier Extensibility Model" was presented as the implementation guideline for the Clean Core strategy.

  • Tier 1: Use only cloud-native public APIs (Clean)

  • Tier 2: Wrappers for when public APIs are unavailable (Conditionally Clean)

  • Tier 3: Traditional ABAP coding (Not Clean)

This model was extremely stoic, creating strong pressure that "anything other than the latest cloud practices (Tier 1) is unacceptable."

However, within the JSUG Technical Committee, we repeatedly questioned SAP on this point:

"BAPI (Business Application Programming Interface) is a standard interface provided and guaranteed by SAP itself to safely extend standard functions. Isn't it contradictory to label it 'Not Clean' when we are using SAP's own standard?"

From a practical standpoint, forcing a rewrite of BAPIs that have been running stably for over 20 years, simply because they "don't fit Tier 1 practices," cannot be justified in terms of cost-effectiveness.

It turns out we weren't alone. Major user groups worldwide, such as DSAG in Germany and ASUG in the US, provided similar feedback: "Denying existing stable BAPI assets is unrealistic" and "Creating Tier 2 wrappers is wasted effort."

In response to these "voices from the field" from user communities globally, SAP corrected its course between 2024 and 2025, introducing a more realistic and sophisticated new model: "Clean Core Extensibility Levels (A-D Levels)."

(For detailed definitions of each level and a comparison with the 3-Tier model, please refer to the Appendix at the end of this article.)

 

 

A New Evaluation Axis: The Impact of A-D Levels

LevelVerdictDefinition and Interpretation from the Field
Level ACleanInvestment for the Future. The ideal form using the latest ABAP Cloud and Released APIs. New developments should aim for this.
Level BCleanThe Return of BAPI. This is crucial. The use of traditional BAPIs and IDocs (Classic APIs) has been officially recognized as part of "Clean Core." While not "cloud-native," they were evaluated as "Upgrade Safe."
Level CConditionalMonitor Required. Uses non-public internal objects, but risks can be managed via Changelogs, etc.
Level DNot CleanRed Zone. Modifications (direct changes to standard code) and direct table updates. This is the "true technical debt" that must be eliminated.

I evaluate this evolution as SAP prioritizing "substantive system stability" over "formal novelty," thereby regaining engineering integrity. The fact that BAPIs are recognized as "Clean" (even if at a certain level) maintains consistency with the past, providing a significant and realistic solution for us user companies migrating existing assets (Brownfield).

 

 

Why "Standardization" Again Now? — AI as the "New Evaluator"

Just because BAPI usage is allowed (Level B) doesn't mean we should continue with old-school add-on development habits. There is a decisive difference from the past: the "Rise of AI."

In the past, the ones interpreting the data generated by our unique add-on functions were "humans" who were trained to understand it. Humans could supplement "context" to work around slightly malformed data structures.

However, Generative AI (like SAP Joule) is different.

For AI to correctly interpret data and provide smart answers, the data model must be standard, and its meaning (Semantics) must be defined. Here, the relationship between "Z-tables (Add-on tables)" and "CDS Views" becomes critical.

 

Technical Deep Dive: Why Does AI Hate "Z-Tables"?

  • The Limit of Z-Tables (Lack of Context)

    The add-on tables (Z-tables) we have built for years are, to AI, just "mysterious data boxes." For example, if there is a column named VAL1 in a table called Z_SALES_TBL, the program logic might treat it as an order amount, but the database definition itself holds no such meaning.

    If AI looks at this table, it can't understand "what VAL1 is." It will either give a wrong answer (Hallucination) or say "I can't answer."

  • The Role of CDS Views (Injecting Meaning)

    In contrast, CDS (Core Data Services) Views, recommended in S/4HANA, attach "Semantic Labels" to data.

    By defining semantics like "This field is a 'Currency Code'," AI can understand the meaning of the data without looking inside the program logic.

In other words, the modern definition of "Clean" has shifted. It's not just about whether the code sits on BTP (Level A) or S/4HANA (Level B); it's about "whether your data is in a state that is 'interpretable' (Semantic Rich) by AI and the outside world through CDS Views."

 

 

"3 New Yardsticks" to Evaluate Your System

To answer the user's question—"How should we evaluate it?"—I would like to share the following evaluation axes based on a business perspective, premised on SAP's A-D Levels (technical indicators).

 

1. Business Fit & Metabolism

It's not just "Are we using standard functions?", but "Can we make the decision to discard functions that don't generate competitiveness?"

In terms of the A-D model, thoroughly eliminate Level D (Modifications), and even for Level B (BAPI), discard (Retire) those with low business value. This "metabolism" is what matters.

The "6R" Decluttering

  • Retire: Most important. Discard unused code.

  • Repurchase: Switch to SaaS or standard functions.

  • Refactor: Rebuild only differentiating areas in Level A (ABAP Cloud/BTP).

  • Re-platform: Recognize Level B (Classic API) as status quo. However, a repayment plan is needed.

 

2. Delivery Agility (Speed & Safety)

It's not "Are we using BTP?", but "Has the frequency of functional releases improved?"

If you are developing on the cloud but the lead time for a release takes months, the architecture or process is wrong. Like DORA metrics, use metrics like Change Lead Time and Deployment Frequency as your guide.

More Detail: Moving from "Developer's Intuition" to a "Decision Map (Framework)"

When considering agility, it is also necessary to examine architecture and the technologies adopted. In response to the question, "Should this function be built inside S/4HANA (On-Stack) or out on BTP (Side-by-Side)?", SAP provides a standard decision-making guide called the "SAP Application Extension Methodology (AEM)."

  • Phase 1: Is an extension actually necessary in the first place? (Decomposition of business requirements)

  • Phase 2: Is the need for UI, logic, or data? (Evaluation of technical characteristics)

  • Phase 3: Which technology is the optimal solution? (Decision via Decision Tree)

These can help maintain a consistent architecture as an organization.

Furthermore, to prevent development on BTP from becoming a "lawless zone," "Golden Paths" are essential. To explain this descriptively, you can think of it as a set that combines "development standards" and "development guidelines" (which are mainly documents and rules) with concrete "mechanisms" to actually streamline and automate the work. In this context, active consideration should be given to utilizing new (modern) technologies such as the following:

  • Write Declaratively (CAP/RAP): Instead of writing extensive procedural steps as done traditionally, shift to a style using CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model) or RAP (ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model) to define "data models and intent." This reduces code volume and increases affinity with AI.

  • Make Loosely Coupled (Event Mesh): Instead of tightly binding systems with APIs, adopt an event-driven architecture to reduce dependencies between systems.

 

3. Data & AI Readiness

"Is your company's data managed in a state that AI can understand?"

Are major data points accessible via standard tables or CDS Views (Semantic Views)? Regardless of whether the implementation is Level A or B, whether the data model has semantic definitions will be the watershed moment for future AI utilization.

 

 

Conclusion: The Essence is "Organization Based on Business Goals"

Looking only at the superficial meaning of the word "Clean Core" is dangerous. What is truly needed is the principle—"organizing what to use (Standard) and what to make (Differentiation) based on business goals." This is an extremely obvious, yet difficult-to-execute principle.

The fact that SAP shifted its policy from the 3-Tier model to the A-D model and reinstated BAPI is a result of us, the user community, raising our voices and engaging in dialogue with the vendor. Without community discussion, idealistic theories detached from reality might have remained the rule.

"Clean Core" initiatives are not just about code on ECC, but a problem for the entire enterprise system. Furthermore, it is not a one-time initiative just for the timing of the upgrade from ECC.

The introduction of the A-D model and the recognition of existing asset utilization (Level B), including BAPI, is good news for us as it "lowers the hurdle for migration evaluation." However, we must not be complacent and leave systems "pickled" in their old state. This is because AI, the new "evaluator," is constantly questioning the quality of system data.

Completing this principle, which has flowed continuously since the era of BAPI integration, not as a technical theory but as a fundamental and management theory because we now have the new weapon of AI—that is the path to the "True Clean Core" we should aim for.

I hope that this place (SAP Community) and user communities like JSUG continue to be places that do not just accept idealisms or buzzwords, but bring together these on-the-ground realities to fight out essential debates and deepen our collective knowledge.

I would be very happy to hear your opinions on this matter as well.

Finally, I would like to use this space to express my gratitude to the opinion leaders who always engage in and deepen these debates, the SAP folks who support us, the SAP Community members who provide new insights, and K.U. who gave me this "Question." (And also to the AI assistant who ran around gathering information and answering my doubts.)

Appendix: Report Summary

Paradigm Shift in Extensibility Models for SAP S/4HANA Clean Core Strategy

The following are the key points from the research report that formed the basis of this article:

1. Background and Issues

The traditional "3-Tier Model" had a strong tendency to label anything other than cloud-native (Tier 1) as "Not Clean," making it difficult for Japanese companies with large amounts of stable existing ABAP assets to implement. User communities like JSUG pointed out the contradiction that "even extensions using BAPI, an SAP standard function, are denied."

2. Detailed Definition of New Model (A-D Levels)

SAP redefined extensibility into four maturity levels and presented practical operational guidelines.

  • Level A (Clean Core / Future Safe):

    • Definition: Uses only Released APIs. Implementation on ABAP Cloud or BTP.

    • Recommendation: First choice for new development. Optimal for AI utilization.

  • Level B (Clean Core / Upgrade Safe):

    • Definition: Extensions using Classic APIs (BAPI, IDoc, RFC, etc.) and Classic Frameworks (ALV, Dynpro, etc.).

    • Difference from 3-Tier: This is the core of the paradigm shift. In the 3-Tier model, these were considered "Tier 3 (Not Clean)" or required concealment as "Tier 2 (Wrapper Creation)."

    • Innovation: In the new model, directly calling BAPIs without creating wrappers has been officially certified as "Clean Core". This means that a massive amount of existing code, which was considered "stable but not cloud-ready because it's old," now reaches the passing grade without modification.

  • Level C (Conditional / Monitor):

    • Definition: Extensions using non-public internal objects but are permitted provided risks are monitored and managed via change logs (Changelog / SYCM).

    • Difference from 3-Tier: The gray zone, which was uniformly considered "Tier 3 (Prohibited)" in the past, has been given the right to exist as "Managed Risk". It functions as a realistic workaround when no alternative API exists.

  • Level D (Not Clean / High Risk):

    • Definition: Modifications, direct table updates. Immediate elimination/renovation is required.

3. Strategic Implications

Level B certification allows for alleviating cost pressures in Brownfield migrations while concentrating resources on eliminating Level D (true debt). This represents a shift from "ideal" to "realistic solution," enhancing the effectiveness of the Clean Core strategy.

Reference Information & Related Links

The following discussions and materials were referenced in writing this article. Please use them for deeper learning.

  • Critical Considerations on Clean Core

    • “Keep the core clean” statement considered harmful (Wout de Waal's Blog): A must-read article sounding the alarm on the misunderstandings invited by "Clean Core" and the complexity of distributed systems (Distributed Monolith).

    • (https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/quot-keep-the-core-clean-quot-statement-considered-harmful/ba-p/13568928)

  • SAP Official Clean Core & Extension Strategy (A-D Model)

    • Clean Core Extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud (SAP Whitepaper): The official whitepaper defining the latest extension models (Clean Core Levels A-D) and governance.

    • (https://www.sap.com/documents/2024/09/20aece06-d87e-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html)

  • Criteria for System Extension

    • SAP Application Extension Methodology: The official methodology and decision tree for deciding "Should we build On-Stack or Side-by-Side?".

    • (https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-btp-guidance-framework/sap-application-extension-methodology/sap-application-extension-methodology-overview)

  • Agility Evaluation Metrics (DORA Metrics)

    • Understanding DORA: A DevOps Guide for Side-by-Side Extension Developers: An explanation on applying Google's DevOps research (DORA) to SAP BTP development to measure delivery performance.

    • (https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/understanding-dora-a-devops-guide-for-side-by-side-extension-developers/ba-p/14226907)

entry.title: Re: SAP CALM API returns forbidden / 403 (in postman)
entry.content: Hi @friscas ,

entry.title: Re: SAP CALM API returns forbidden / 403 (in postman)
entry.content:
Hi @friscas,

I tested the API in Postman successfully, and adding those parameters to the URL was not required for my tests.
The grant_type client_credentials , was automatically included in the body of the authentication call, so it does not need to be added to the URL parameters.

I believe the 403 error you are receiving is due to the absence of the two scopes mentioned in the official documentation (https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/apis/enabling-sap-cloud-alm-apis)  to the API service instance of SAPCloudALMAPIs :

- $XSMASTERAPPNAME.calm-api.features.read

- $XSMASTERAPPNAME.calm-api.features.write

There is also no need to add scopes in the OAuth2 authentication call — they will be retrieved directly from the service instance.

Hope this helps.
Kader Kara

hello All! 

Could anyone assist me? I’m creating a CompositeProvider in Eclipse for BW/4HANA modeling. I need to filter records for Transfer Postings, so I applied the MASSN code Z7 in PA0000 to extract all transfer-posting cases. To retrieve the latest updated information, I’m joining these PERNRs with PA0001, applying the filter ENDDA = 31.12.9999, so I can get the corresponding PERSK and PERSG values for the most current records.

Since the PA0001 data is available through the standard InfoObject 0EMPLOYEE_ATTR, I use that to retrieve PERSG and PERSK. However, for PA0000, I created a custom DataSource with code to extract the required MASSN-based records.

 

define view ZCDS_PA0000_Z7 as select from pa0000

 

 

{

key concat( pernr, begda )as ZCONC_KEY_UNIQUE,

 

key pernr,

key begda,

// key endda,

massn

}

 

where

 

//massn = 'Z4'

//or

massn = 'Z7'

 

Here is the rephrased version in a clear and professional way:

I mapped the start date (BEGDA) field to the standard InfoObject 0VALIDFROM.
When I run the InfoObject independently, it works fine and returns accurate results.
However, when I combine it with 0EMPLOYEE_ATTR, the output becomes incorrect for the condition ENDDA = 31.12.9999.

Whether I use a left outer join or an inner join, the issue remains the same:

  • PA0000 gives 199 records (MASSN = Z7)

  • PA0001 / 0EMPLOYEE_ATTR gives 153 updated records

  • But in the CompositeProvider, it still shows 199 records instead of 153, even though 0EMPLOYEE_ATTR should return only the updated records.

I am not sure why this mismatch is happening, since 0EMPLOYEE_ATTR is supposed to provide only the latest active record with ENDDA = 31.12.9999.

entry.title: How to generate Attendance quota PA2007 from Time evaluation
S/4HANA Group Reporting - Group View on Accounting (GVA)
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog, we will discuss about the new Review Booklet app Group View on Accounting (GVA). The app provides a group view access of high granular and anytime access to the most recent Accounting data. The look and feel of the report is very similar to our existing reports in Group Reporting but based out of accounting data. A new analytical stack brings the data from accounting table ACDOCA and combines the existing Group Reporting analytical stack to deliver the results for this report to provide a Group View to end users. 

GVA Columns

  • Column 1: “Accounting”: The measures reflects the accounting data (ACDOCA). It includes both released and unreleased data.
  • Column 2: “Accounting released”: The measures reflects the accounting release data that is as per the Entry timestamp of ACDOCA table <= release time stamp (table RTC_PULL_REQ)
  • Column 3: “Accounting unreleased”: The measures reflects the unreleased data that is as per Entry timestamp of ACDOCA > release time  stamp  (table RTC_PULL_REQ) 
  • Column 4.1: “GR released”: The measures reflects the released data of Group Reporting as per PL blank ACDOCU table and consider the record type = U (only) (ACDOCU)
  • Column 4.2: “GR adjusted” (PL blank CT, ANI): The measure  reflects the CT and ANI of GR that is nothing but as as per PL blank of ACDOCU table 
  • Column 4.3: “GR corrected”: The measures reflects that manual postings that is as per PL 00, 01, 0C of Group Reporting Journals (ACDOCU)
  • Column 5: “Delta GR Acctg. Released”: Column 4.1 - Column 2 (should always display a zero ) 

Pre-Requisites

The following are the pre-requisites for the proper functioning of the app

  • The GRPL fields should be enabled
  • Map FS items with G/L accounts
  • The consolidation unit should be enabled for "Transfer From Universal Journal"

How unreleased data is reflected in the Review Booklet?

Please refer to the below video on how the data is reflected on the accounting unreleased column.

How Released data is reflected in the Review Booklet? 

Please refer to the below video on How the data is reflected on the accounting released and GR released  column.

Also, releasing the ANI/CT task the data will be reflected in  GR Retranslated as shown below.

 

Navigation

For the accounting columns you will be able to navigate to the Trial Balance app, provided the end user posses the necessary role as shown below.

 

Similarly you can navigate to Group Financial Statement app as shown below for Group Reporting columns:

 

Extensibility - Custom Fields

The fields need to be mapped in the SSCUI app Data Release Task: Define Mapping for Jrnl. You can map an existing or static field of General Ledger(ACDOCA) to a custom field in Group Journal(ACDOCU). Similarly, you can also map a custom field of General Ledger to a custom field in Group Journal as shown below.

The custom fields appear in the review booklet as shown below:

 

Commenting

The commenting feature offers the following:

  • You can create, edit and display data cell  or page comments
  • Cell icon appears only when the navigation state matches at the time of creation of the comments
  • You can classify the comments as Critical, Important, Medium, Low or None
  • A status (Open, In Process, or Resolved) can be set to the comments
  • You can tag a comment

Please refer to the screenshot below:

 

Summary

  • New group financial review app on real-time accounting data​
  • Expose universal ledger accounting data into an analytical group view through this new SAP Fiori app 
  • Integrate with group reporting for tighter accounting​
  • Leverage the app to review group financial statements​
  • New features of the new SAP Fiori app for readily consumed reporting content in different pages based on master data from group reporting and reporting rule definitions:​
    • Balance sheet​
    • Profit and loss statement (cost of sales and nature of expense structure)​
    • Cash flow statement​
  • Predefined column and row structures:​
    • Data release status to group reporting (Accounting data, released data in group reporting)​
    • Period comparison reporting (such as prior-year)​
    • Organizational hierarchies (consolidation unit, segment, and profit center)​
    • Various measures, including  quarter comparison, and year to date, as well as local currency, transaction currency, group currency, and quantity​
  • Navigation and drill-through capabilities to  (depending on the source of data)​:​
    • Group Financial Review Booklet​ 
    • Trial Balance - accounting 
  • Commenting feature for data cell and page comments

Conclusion

Please feel free to share your thoughts by commenting on this blog. Also, we can use this blog as a communication tool for any clarification that you require on this topic. You can also follow my profile for more content on analytical application for group reporting. I would recommend posting your questions by specifying the tag: “SAP S/4HANA Finance for group reporting”

entry.title: Re: Emergency: Affecting 100 people,Acct cant enter into...
entry.content:
Hi @frezhang ,
Please start by checking OBY6 company code parameters — that’s the most common reason why the BR chart of accounts cannot be selected. Following action must be taken to fix the issue.

Check Company Code Settings (OBY6), Ensure the Brazilian company code has, Chart of Accounts: YCOA and Alternative Chart of Accounts: YCBR

Verify Chart of Accounts Definition (OB13), Confirm YCOA and YCBR are both defined and ensure YCBR is flagged as alternative.

Map Accounts (FS00 / FS02):
For each operational account in YCOA, assign the corresponding YCBR account in the Alternative Account Number field.

Authorization Check, Run SU53 for affected users to see missing authorizations. Ensure roles allow access to BR account table.

System Sync, If this is in the Brazilian National Public Cloud, confirm that the integration layer is active and synchronized.

Establish a mapping table between YCOA ↔ YCBR for all accounts.
Automate assignment during account creation.
Train users to maintain both sets of accounts consistently.
Document the configuration in SAP Solution Manager for audit compliance.

entry.title: Re: How can we print a cancelled FINT Invoice. (SAP ECC6)
entry.content:
Hi @palmeram,
In SAP ECC6, cancelled FINT (Interest) invoices do not automatically generate a printout. To provide customers with a cancellation invoice, you need to configure the output determination (via transaction NACE) so that the cancellation document triggers a print form. Alternatively, you can use FINTSHOW to display the cancellation and then set up a custom output type or SmartForm to print it.

Let me know if you need to explain more about output configuration in NACE

entry.title: Re: Some user can not see the price for purchase order
entry.content:
Hi,

Please use this Business Add-In (BAdI) Change of Field Control for Purchase Order Items (MM_PUR_S4_PO_FLDCNTRL_SIMPLE) is used in the Purchasing (MM-PUR-PO) component.

You use this BAdI to change the field control in the purchase order apps .

You can use BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PO_FLDCNTRL_SIMPLE to modify the properties of specific fields that appear on the user interface of the apps:

  • Manage Purchase Orders on item level in the section Process Control
  • Create Purchase Order - Advanced on item level on the tabs Delivery and Invoice.

The SAP GUI transactions ME21N, ME22N, ME23N are also affected by this
BAdI.
You can make the fields hidden, read-only, mandatory, or optional as per
your requirements.

Using the BAdI you can change the field control properties for the
following attributes:

  • Goods Receipt GOODSRECEIPTISEXPECTED
  • Non-Valuated Goods Receipt GOODSRECEIPTISNONVALUATED
  • Invoice Receipt INVOICEISEXPECTED
  • Goods-Receipt-Based Invoice Verification INVOICEISGOODSRECEIPTBASED
  • Final Invoice ISFINALLYINVOICED
  • Delivery Completed ISCOMPLETELYDELIVERED
  • Tax Code TAXCODE
  • Net Price Amount NETPRICEAMOUNT
  • Expected Value EXPECTEDOVERALLLIMITAMOUNT
  • Overall Limit OVERALLLIMITAMOUNT
  • Contract for Limit PURCONTRACTFOROVERALLLIMIT
  • Service Performer SERVICEPERFORMER
  • Incoterms INCOTERMSCLASSIFICATION
  • Shipping Instructions SHIPPINGINSTRUCTION

Refer to KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/3268822

Thank you,

SAP Support

entry.title: LLM大语言模型常见概念介绍
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

你有没有好奇过，当你问ChatGPT一个问题时，它的"大脑"里到底发生了什么？

今天我们就来拆解这个黑盒子，用最简单的方式理解AI是如何工作的。

 

LLM的基本组成：AI的"大脑"构造

LLM主要由两个核心部分组成：

神经网络（Neural Network）：

神经网络本体由数以千亿个相互连接的"神经元"组成

每个神经元都存储着微小的"知识片段"

神经元之间互相连接，可以传递和组合信息

神经元的数量就是我们常说的LLM模型的参数数量，一般情况来说，神经元越多，模型越聪明（这个规律也被称为Scaling Law）

 

翻译器（Tokenizer）：语言的"耳朵"和"嘴巴"

翻译器就像是大脑的感官系统，负责在人类语言和机器语言之间进行转换：

"耳朵"功能：将听到的内容（例如文本）转换成大脑能理解的"神经信号"（数字向量）

"嘴巴"功能：将大脑的"思考结果"重新翻译成我们能理解的自然语言

就像我们听到声音后大脑要先处理成神经信号才能理解一样，LLM也需要这个翻译器来"听懂"和"说出"人话。

 

LLM常见应用场景详解

训练（Training）：LLM的"求学过程"

就像一个婴儿学习说话的过程

刚被创建的神经网络内神经元的内容是随机的，需要经过训练，修改神经元内容，才会让LLM变聪明

而训练过程就像玩猜字游戏，训练员给到一段文字，让大脑猜测这段文字的下一个字是什么，如果猜错了，训练员就会根据猜测结果与正确答案的偏差程度来修改神经元内容

这样，3个字的输入数据ABC就可以产生2次训练结果，分别是根据A来猜测B，和根据AB来猜测C

这个过程中，神经元内存放的信息会持续改变，LLM也就在这个过程中变得更聪明

 

但纯文本训练而来的LLM的对话风格，价值观等是由训练数据决定的，错误价值观很容易造成严重后果

而我们很难人为判断数据是否合适，进而“规训”LLM的价值观

所以有一种特殊训练方式：

RLHF（人类反馈强化学习）- AI的"价值观教育"

就是让LLM对一个问题生成多个回答，由人类标注哪个回答更好，来训练LLM，以让LLM的回答更符合人类倾向

如果你在使用AI时遇到它问你两类答案哪个你更喜欢，不用怀疑，你正在训练LLM

 

常见名词解释：

推理（Inference）：LLM的"即时思考"

就是LLM接收信息，返回结果的过程

这个过程中，神经元内存放的信息是不变的

 

微调（Fine-tuning）：LLM的"继续教育"

就是以较低成本训练，优化LLM。成本降序排列如下:

  • 可以按照正常训练模式，继续修改全量神经元的信息，但这样需要大量数据和算力
  • 也可以将部分神经元冻结，后续训练只会选择性的更新未冻结神经元的信息
  • 还可以添加一组辅助神经网络，新训练只修改辅助神经网络，不同任务对应不同的辅助神经网络

 

还有一些不修改参数，不进行训练的优化方式：

1.角色扮演提示：通过告诉LLM要扮演什么角色来快速的规范LLM的回答

例如：

普通问法：翻译这句话：How are you

优化问法：你是一名15年经验的专业英文翻译，请翻译这句话

 

2.零样本提示：通过明确任务描述与要求的方式来优化表现

普通问法："翻译这句话：How are you"

优化问法："请将以下中文翻译成地道的英文，注意保持原意和语气：How are you"

 

3.少样本提示：在零样本的基础上给出几组范例

例如：

"请按照以下格式回答：

例子1：问题：苹果是什么颜色？回答：苹果通常是红色或绿色的。

例子2：问题：猫会飞吗？回答：猫不会飞，它们是陆地动物。

现在请回答：狗喜欢什么？"

 

4.思维链提示：以思维链的方式解决问题，并作为范例发送

例如：

"问题：咖啡店有23个顾客，又来了15个，然后走了9个，现在有多少顾客？

思考过程：最开始有23个顾客，来了15个后是23+15=38个，走了9个后是38-9=29个。

答案：29个顾客。

现在请用同样的方式解决这个问题：

学校有87个学生，转走了12个，又转来了8个，现在有多少学生？"

 

总结

LLM就像一个拥有千亿神经元的"大脑"，配备翻译器来理解和输出人类语言。

它通过训练不断学习知识，通过推理回答问题，还可以用微调和提示优化等方式提升表现。

简单来说，LLM就是在通过数学的方式模拟人类的学习、思考和交流过程。

entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration - Upgrade Readiness Design Guidelines/Best Practices for Future Readiness
entry.content:
Introduction

Have you ever wondered where to start to understand the benefits of upgrade readiness design guidelines for your cloud integration system and how to achieve them? Then this blog post is for you! It brings you in-depth insights into the upgrade readiness concept and its implementation, with resources to help make your integration artifacts, prominently Groovy scripts, future-proof.

Whether you're developing integration scenarios in SAP Integration Suite or refining existing ones, this is your guide to ensuring long-term stability, maintainability, and resilience - even in the face of major runtime upgrades.

In this blog post, you will understand the detailed aspects of upgrade readiness, its objectives, principles and how to leverage in the integration flow tooling. With the 7.45 version in NEO and 6.72/8.36 in Cloud foundry release,  SAP Cloud Integration provides a upgrade readiness feature.

Why is Upgrade Readiness Essential?

One of the most powerful features of SAP Cloud Integration is the Groovy flow step, which allows developers to write custom Groovy scripts to solve complex problems efficiently. However, these scripts can create risks for future upgrades, especially when they rely on:

  • Unsupported system classes.
  • Internal Apache Camel framework classes.
  • Undocumented Java libraries.

Using these internal or unsupported classes may not only result in incompatibility during major runtime upgrades but can make the system fragile and prone to failures, something many of you may have experienced during previous major version upgrades.

What is Upgrade Readiness?

Upgrade readiness is a set of best practices, guidelines, rules, or tools designed to ensure scripts are clean, consistent, and ready for future upgrades. It promotes a development approach that helps maintain the stability and reliability of integration artifacts and minimizes the risk of breakdown during major runtime version upgrades in SAP Integration Suite.

Here’s how upgrade readiness can help:

  1. Restrict Usage of Internal APIs: Avoid APIs that are unsupported or pose risks during upgrades.
  2. Identify Violations in Groovy Scripts: Detect and fix problematic script patterns, such as unused imports or usage of internal APIs.
  3. Encourage Using Recommended Libraries and Standards: Build scripts that align with SAP's recommended practices and approved APIs.

Upgrade Readiness Guidelines

Adhering to these guidelines promotes a robust, scalable architecture that withstands future system upgrades. Let’s explore key considerations.

Remove Unused Imports

Unused imports create unnecessary complications during software or runtime upgrades:

  • Avoid compilation/runtime errors: Unused imports might reference deprecated libraries or classes, potentially breaking the script.
  • Eliminate visual clutter: It helps streamline script functionality while avoiding confusion about dependencies.

Best Practice: Scan all Groovy scripts for unused imports and remove them to ensure clean and efficient code.

Use Recommended Libraries and Classes

A crucial step in creating upgrade-ready artifacts is using only recommended or SAP-approved libraries and APIs:

  • Avoid Internal Classes: Replace direct usage of internal classes (e.g., Apache Camel) with SAP-provided APIs and extensions.
  • Leverage supported libraries: Always rely on SAP APIs for safe system interactions, reducing risks from dependency issues during updates.
  • Bundle custom libraries carefully: If a critical library isn’t provided by SAP, include it as part of your integration flow. However, be aware that this may impact flow size and startup performance.
  • Restrict OS/Network access: Avoid direct file/system operations; use alternatives provided by SAP.

Examples of unsupported classes to avoid:

  • System.exit() or TimeZone.setDefault()
  • Direct access to environment variables using System.getenv() or System.getProperty()
  • Console outputs like System.out.println()

Instead, use alternatives like SAP API com.sap.it.script.system.Properties for environment-safe interactions.

Refer KBA to know the list of incompatible internal classes.

Plan Proactive Cleanup of Existing Scripts

As part of preparing your system for future upgrades, ensure current scripts are compliant with upgrade readiness guidelines.

  • Start cleanup processes for existing artifacts adhering to the new framework.
  • Focus on creating awareness among development teams about unsupported script patterns.
  • Get familiar with the upgrade readiness toolset in SAP Integration Suite.

Upgrade Readiness Objectives and Strategy

Upgrade readiness is more than just avoiding future system breakdowns; it’s about establishing a future-proof integration development model.

Objectives:

  1. Enable future proofing: Build robust integration artifacts that are immune to frequent version upgrades.
  2. Ensure maintainability: Maintain clean, stable, and compatible integration scripts.
  3. Reduce upgrade risks: Proactively address dependencies on unsupported libraries and APIs.

Strategy:

  • Introduce upgrade compliance guidelines for current SAP Cloud Integration stacks (NEO, CF) to foster awareness.
  • Collaborate with teams to initiate self-service cleanup of existing artifacts.
  • Provide training and resources to ensure developers are well-versed in upgraded best practices.

Upgrade Readiness Principles

  1. Code Cleanliness

    • Remove unused imports.
    • Write concise, maintainable scripts.

  2. Avoid Unsupported APIs and Classes

    • Avoid internal, deprecated, or system-level APIs.
    • Refrain from direct OS manipulations.

  3. Use Recommended Libraries and APIs

    • Use SAP-provided or approved APIs.
    • Replace unsupported libraries with standard alternatives.

  4. Plan for Future Compatibility

    • Design artifacts resilient to runtime upgrades.
    • Ensure compatibility with future software updates.

  5. Reduce Code and Visual Clutter

    • Eliminate unnecessary logs and code blocks.
    • Keep scripts streamlined and easy to understand.

  6. Enable Proactive Cleanup

    • Regularly review and update integration artifacts.
    • Clean up older stacks like NEO and CF deployments.

  7. Avoid Operating System Manipulations

    • Avoid direct OS interactions.
    • Use platform-provided APIs for secure operations.

  8. Train Teams on Best Practices

    • Educate developers on best practices.
    • Promote awareness of upgrade readiness tools.

  9. Utilize Upgrade Readiness Tools

    • Use tools to monitor for violations.
    • Proactively identify and resolve issues.

Implementing these principles ensures stable, future-proof integration artifacts.

Steps to Apply Upgrade Readiness

Applying upgrade readiness and future-proofing your integration artifacts involves following a set of best practices and utilizing the tools provided within the integration platform. Below, we outline the steps to achieve this:

Access Integration Settings Page

    • Navigate to the Integration Settings page.
    • Here, you will find the newly introduced upgrade readiness design guidelines, which are activated by default

Open Integration Flow Editor

    • Access the integration flow editor where you design and manage your integration artifacts.
    • You will notice the same set of upgrade readiness design guidelines applicable here.

Execute Guidelines and Check Compliance Status

    • Execute the guidelines to see the compliance status of your integration artifacts.
    • Specifically check for non-compliant Groovy flow steps. Analysis feature will show the list of affected groovy scripts. Check the version of the groovy script as well.

Open the Script Editor

    • Open the script editor to examine the issues highlighted in the problems view.
    • Note that upgrading to Groovy step 2.x can fix crucial violations related to internal Camel and stack class usage.

 


Apply Fixes and Recommendations

    • Follow the suggested fixes and recommendations to make your Groovy scripts future-ready.
    • Save the Groovy script by clicking Apply and then close the editor to return to the integration flow editor.

 

Save the Integration Flow

    • Save your integration flow to ensure that all changes are persisted.
    • Verify the version of the Groovy flow step is updated to 2.x.

Re-evaluate Compliance

    • After applying the upgrades, execute the guidelines again to ensure that the previously violated Groovy steps are now compliant.

Important Note

  • You can leverage the public OData Remote APIs to read, execute and download the guidelines at the integration flow artifact level. This will promote the automation.
  • Refer to the documentation for details: Integration Flow Design Guidelines.

Why Groovy Script 2.x?

Upgrading to Groovy script 2.x provides several benefits:

  • Future-Ready Scripts: Automatic fixes for incompatible libraries and classes prepare your scripts for future major version runtime and software upgrades.
  • Advanced Groovy Features: Utilizes Groovy runtime 4.0.29, providing access to modern language elements such as switch expressions and other capabilities. You can refer the groovy 4.0.29 for more details.

Handling Non-Compatibility

If the updated version of the Groovy step does not yield the expected result then take the below measures.

  1. Downgrade Groovy Script: You can downgrade the Groovy script step and revert to the older version.
  2. Create a ServiceNow ticket : Document the issue and create a ticket using the component LOD-HCI-PI-WT-IFL for further assistance. Issue will be fixed as per the SLA.
  3. Adapt Processes: Adapt your business processes to accommodate the upgraded script to stay prepared for future upgrades. You should strive to be on the major version of the script step.

By following these steps, you can ensure that your integration artifacts are compliant with the latest guidelines and ready for future upgrades.

What’s coming next

  • Upgrade Readiness Guidelines for JavaScript.
  • Execute Design Guidelines Automatically on Artifact Save.
  • Block Artifact Deployment if Guidelines Are Violated, Governed by Tenant Administrator.
  • Central Dashboard Displaying All Incompatible Scripts at Tenant Level.

Share your feedback in the comment section on these upcoming innovations and provide your remarks on the prioritization.

Other source of material

  • Upgrade groovy script
  • new design guideline: recommended classes 
  • KBA Article

I hope you find the enhancements in this blog post beneficial. If you have any questions or feedback, please leave a comment.

entry.title: Requirement for Percentage or Equivalence Number for Co-Product in Process Order – SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Hello @Chris1973 ,

I am facing a particular issue when creating a process order in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, specifically related to the handling of co-products.

In the Bill of Materials (BOM), the material in question is correctly configured as a co-product. Likewise, in MM02, the material is also marked as a co-product in the relevant views. However, when generating the process order, the system still requires me to enter a percentage or an equivalence number for this co-product before allowing the order to be saved.

As additional context, the header material in the BOM has a base quantity of 1000 kg, while the co-product in its corresponding BOM position has a quantity of 308 kg.

Therefore, I would like to ask: Where in the BOM structure or configuration should these percentages or equivalence factors be defined so that the system does not request them again during the creation of the process order?
If there is any additional configuration required for co-products in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, I would greatly appreciate your guidance.

Additionally, if anyone else in the community has experienced a similar situation or knows why this behavior occurs, I would be very interested in learning how you resolved it.

Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: Re: Change financial statement versions in Company Profit...
entry.content:
Hello @suyoung_choi3 ,

Please find the following help document for your reference:

Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) | SAP Help Portal

Semantic tags are textual identifiers used to highlight key figures in financial statement versions (FSVs). These tags are linked to FSV structures, easing the calculation of metrics and key performance indicators (KPIs) for analytical reporting. Beyond FSV YPS2, you can construct your own FSV using the semantic tags from the SAP template, and assign your own GL Account. These custom tags need to be associated with the correct financial statement versions (FSVs).

You need to assign your own FSV to the semantic tags mentioned in the help link, or change the related node in the YPS2 related to these semantic tags.

Kind Regards,

entry.title: regarding Backorder Processing (BOP)
entry.content:
Hi Experts!

I have a question regarding Backorder Processing (BOP).

Please see the scenario below:

* **Inventory:** 3,000 kg
* **Sales Orders (SOs):**
* SO 1: 1,000 kg (**Credit Blocked**)
* SO 2: 1,000 kg (**Credit Blocked**)
* SO 3: 1,000 kg (**Credit Blocked**)

*Note: When SOs 1 through 3 were initially created, stock was unavailable, resulting in a **zero confirmed quantity** in VA03.*

When **BOP** is executed in this state, the log shows a **Credit Warning and Saved** status for SOs 1 through 3.
However, when checking the schedule lines in **VA03**, the confirmed quantity remains zero.
In contrast, the **Product Available Stock Inquiry App (F7884)** shows 3,000 kg as **Reserved** for future requirements.

The next day, when Sales Order 4 (1,000 kg) is created, it also fails to obtain a confirmed quantity.

We would like to understand the technical reason for this behavior: why is the stock internally reserved or consumed (preventing SO 4 from obtaining it), yet the confirmed quantity remains zero in VA03?

Best Regards,
S-O

entry.title: Re: Bringing the SAP Fiori Development Portal and Its Use to the Next Level (6 of 6)
entry.content:
Hi Community,

" 

  • Leverage Global Patterns early in your project planning - these non-visual building blocks like draft handling and navigation patterns are often overlooked but critical for enterprise applications   
  • Evaluate standard floorplans against your use cases before building custom solutions - List Report and Object Page patterns handle the majority of business scenarios. Together with the extension points provided by SAP Fiori elements, they can often meet your requirements with minimal effort
  • Use Custom Pages for more creative app layouts - if the target picture of your application is too far from the standard floorplans, opt for custom page creation using building blocks and global patterns to get the benefits of the metadata-driven UIs, or leverage freestyle SAPUI5 to achieve your goal. "

 

Thanks for your selfless sharing, it really help us a lot.

 

🙂

Regards,

ZFiori.
